svcproc.title: SERVICE CHECKS
svcproc.para: Often a valve is unnecessarily replaced. There are basic steps to be performed to determine if the valve is defective or if proper adjustment has not been performed. To determine the status of a valve, perform the following service checks:

step1.para: Assure that brake air reservoir pressure is at governor cut-off pressure or about 100 psi. If the air pressure at the control valves is significantly less than system air pressure, check the air lines for any restrictions and check the pressure protection valve for proper operation.

Raise height control valve lever approximately 45 degrees above horizontal. Air pressure at the air springs should begin to increase within 15 seconds which will cause the truck frame to rise. This can easily be detected by feeling the shock absorber extend at the dust tube to shock absorber body joint.
Move the control lever arm to the neutral position. The air flow should stop.
Lower height control valve lever approximately 45 degrees below horizontal. Air should begin to exhaust from the valve within 15 seconds.
Move the control arm to the neutral position. The valve should shut off air flow.
Raise or lower the air pressure in the air springs to achieve the correct air spring height. Refer to RIDE HEIGHT DIMENSION / CODES CHART .
Check valve bodies and all tubing connections and air springs for air leaks using soap and water solution. Correct any leak conditions.
Recheck air spring height 15 minutes after Step 8 above has been completed. If the air spring height has changed, return to Step 8 and repeat operation until the leaks are corrected.
If no leaks are found, and the height control valve functions as described above, and air spring height is at the specified dimension after 15 minutes, the valve is functioning properly.
Refer to Figure 23, and perform the adjustment.
